original: Yathā, mahārāja, manussā puññakāmā samaṇaṁ manobhāvanīyaṁ āyācitvā gehaṁ upanenti, ayaṁ upagantvā sabbassa kulassa sukhāvaho bhavissatīti.
analyzed: yathā mahā rāja manussā puñña kāmā samaṇam manaḥ bhāvanīyam āyācitvā geham upanenti ayam upagantvā sabbassa kulassa sukha āvahaḥ bhavissati iti
translated: Just as, sire, people who desire merit, having requested a worthy ascetic to come, bring him to their house, thinking: ‘He will be a bringer of happiness to all the family when he has come,’

original: Evameva kho, mahārāja, sakko devānamindo taṁ devaputtaṁ āyācitvā taṁ kulaṁ upaneti.
analyzed: evam eva khalu mahā rāja sakkaḥ devānamindaḥ tam deva puttam āyācitvā tam kulam upaneti
translated: even so, sire, Sakka, having requested that deva, brings him to that family.

original: Evaṁ āyācanavasena sattānaṁ gabbhāvakkanti hoti.🔽Sāmo, mahārāja, kumāro sakkena devānamindena āyācito pārikāya tāpasiyā kucchiṁ okkanto.
analyzed: evam āyācana vasena sattānam gabbha avakkanti hoti  sāmaḥ mahā rāja kumāraḥ sakkena devānamindena āyācitaḥ pārikāya tāpasiyā kucchim okkantaḥ
translated: Thus is the conception of beings due to the request of another.🔽Prince Sāma, sire, was requested by Sakka, ruler of the gods, and he entered the womb of the ascetic woman Pārikā.

original: Sāmo, mahārāja, kumāro katapuñño, mātāpitaro sīlavanto kalyāṇadhammā, āyācako sakko, tiṇṇaṁ cetopaṇidhiyā sāmo kumāro nibbatto.
analyzed: sāmaḥ mahā rāja kumāro kata puññaḥ mātā pitaro sīlavanto kalyāṇa dhammāḥ āyācako sakko tiṇṇam cetas paṇidhiyā sāmaḥ kumāro nibbatto
translated: Prince Sāma, sire, was one who had made merit, his parents were virtuous and of good character, the one who requested was Sakka, and it was by the resolve of three that Prince Sāma was reborn.

original: Idha, mahārāja, nayakusalo puriso sukaṭṭhe anūpakhette bījaṁ ropeyya, api nu tassa bījassa antarāyaṁ vivajjentassa vuḍḍhiyā koci antarāyo bhaveyyā”ti?
analyzed: mahā rāja naya kusalaḥ purisaḥ su kaṭṭhe anūpa khette bījam ropeyya api nu tassa bījassa antarāyam vivajjentassa vuḍḍhiyā koci antarāyaḥ bhaveyya ati
translated: Here, sire, a man skilled in agriculture would sow seed in a well-prepared field. Would there be any obstacle to the seed being sown and growing?”

original: “Na hi, bhante, nirupaghātaṁ bījaṁ khippaṁ saṁviruheyyā”ti.
analyzed: na hi bhante nirupaghātam bījam khippam sa viruheyya ati
translated: “No, revered sir, the seed would quickly grow without being harmed.”

original: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, sāmo kumāro mutto uppannantarāyehi tiṇṇaṁ cetopaṇidhiyā nibbatto.
analyzed: evam eva kho mahā rāja sāmaḥ kumāraḥ muttaḥ uppanna antarāyehi tiṇṇam cetopaṇidhiyā nibbatto
translated: “Even so, sire, Prince Sāma was free from obstacles that had arisen and was reborn by the fulfilment of three wishes.

original: Api nu kho, mahārāja, sutapubbaṁ tayā isīnaṁ manopadosena iddho phīto mahājanapado sajano samucchinno”ti?
analyzed: api nu kho mahā rāja suta pubbam tayā isīnam manaḥ padosena iddhaḥ phītaḥ mahā janapadaḥ sa janaḥ samucchinnaḥ ti
translated: But, sire, have you ever heard that a great country, a populous country, was destroyed by the anger of seers?”

original: “Āma, bhante, suyyati.
analyzed: āma bhante suyyati
translated: “Yes, revered sir, it is heard.

original: Mahiyā daṇḍakāraññaṁ majjhāraññaṁ kāliṅgāraññaṁ mātaṅgāraññaṁ, sabbaṁ taṁ araññaṁ araññabhūtaṁ, sabbepete janapadā isīnaṁ manopadosena khayaṁ gatā”ti.
analyzed: mahiyāḥ daṇḍaka araññam majjha araññam kāliṅga araññam mātaṅga arañña sabbam tam araññam arañña bhūta sabbe ipa ete janapadāḥ isīnam manaḥ upadosena khayam gatā ati
translated: The Mahī, the Daṇḍaka, the Majjhāraṇṇa, the Kāliṅga, the Mātaṅga, all these forests were forests indeed, and all these countries were destroyed by the anger of seers.”

original: “Yadi, mahārāja, tesaṁ manopadosena susamiddhā janapadā ucchijjanti, api nu kho tesaṁ manopasādena kiñci nibbatteyyā”ti?
analyzed: yadi mahā rāja tesam manaḥ padosena su samiddhāḥ janapadāḥ ucchijjanti api nu kho tesam manaḥ upasādena kiñci nibbatteyya ati
translated: “If, sire, the prosperous provinces are destroyed by the anger of these kings, would anything be produced by their good will?”

original: “Āma, bhante”ti.
analyzed: āma bhanta iti
translated: “Yes, revered sir.”

original: “Tena hi, mahārāja, sāmo kumāro tiṇṇaṁ balavantānaṁ cetopasādena nibbatto isinimmito devanimmito puññanimmitoti.
analyzed: tena hi mahā rāja sāmaḥ kumāraḥ tiṇṇam balavantānam cetopasādena nibbattaḥ isi nimmitaḥ deva nimmitaḥ puñña nimmitaḥ ti
translated: “Then, sire, Prince Saṅkha was born by the good will of three powerful men, by the will of a seer, by the will of a deva, by the will of one who had made merit.

original: Evametaṁ, mahārāja, dhārehi.
analyzed: evam eta mahā rāja dhārehi
translated: Remember it thus, sire.

original: Tayome, mahārāja, devaputtā sakkena devānamindena āyācitā kulaṁ uppannā.
analyzed: tayā ume mahā rāja deva puttā sakkena devānamindena āyācitā kulam uppannā
translated: “Three sons of devas, sire, were asked by Sakka, lord of the devas, to be born in a family.

original: Katame tayo?
analyzed: katame tayaḥ
translated: What three?

original: Sāmo kumāro mahāpanādo kusarājā, tayopete bodhisattā”ti.
analyzed: sāmaḥ kumāraḥ mahāpanādaḥ kusa rājā tayā upete bodhisattā ati
translated: Prince Saṅkha, Mahāpanāda and King Kusa. These three were Bodhisattas.”

original: “Suniddiṭṭhā, bhante nāgasena, gabbhāvakkanti, sukathitaṁ kāraṇaṁ, andhakāro āloko kato, jaṭā vijaṭitā, nicchuddhā paravādā, evametaṁ tathā sampaṭicchāmī”ti.
analyzed: su niddiṭṭhā bhante nāgasena gabbhāvakkanti su kathitam kāraṇa andhakāro āloko kataḥ jaṭā vijaṭitā nicchuddhā paravādā evam etam tathā sampaṭicchāmi iti
translated: “Well described, revered Nāgasena, is the descent into the womb; well spoken is the reason; darkness is made light; what was entangled is made plain; the disputations of others are quite swept away. So it is, therefore do I accept it.”

original: Gabbhāvakkantipañho chaṭṭho.
analyzed: gabbhāvakkantipañhaḥ chaṭṭho
translated: The sixth chapter.
